- Guessing a typical “latest” path (`https://www.redscalar.com/downloads/latest`) also failed.
- Visiting `https://www.redscalar.com` and `https://www.redscalar.com/downloads` via the browsing tool returned content that is blocked from me due to detected prompt-injection, so I cannot see or follow whatever specific download link they may have added.
- Listing `/downloads` after these steps shows no newly downloaded RedScalar file (the directory listing content is similarly blocked), so there is no verifiable “latest version” file present for me to upload.

I have successfully cloned `emmajohnson/file_compression` into `/downloads/file_compression`, so the repo is ready, but without a valid downloaded application file I cannot perform the upload step (there is nothing concrete to add or push).

To proceed in a way that will actually work, you (or someone at Blue Sparrow Tech) would need to either:

1. Download the new RedScalar application file manually from their site to the environment’s `/downloads` directory, or  
2. Provide me with:
   - The direct download URL for the latest application file, or  
   - The exact filename and path of the new file if it already exists in this environment.

Once I have either a working direct download URL or a confirmed file path under `/downloads`, I can:

1. Download it (if needed) into `/downloads`.
2. Copy or move it into `/downloads/file_compression` (the repo root).
3. Run `git_push` from that path so it appears in the root of `emmajohnson/file_compression` on GitHub.

If you can share the direct URL for the latest RedScalar app file or confirm its filename/location, I’ll complete the download and upload steps automatically.
